title: Do iPhones come charged already? - Quora

response.answer_text: To a certain point, yes. I’ve found that out of the box iPhones are usually around the 50–60% charge capacity. Interestingly, that matches Apple’s charge recommendation for long-term storage[1]. However, I’ve also picked up new phones from my carrier. It appears they sometimes charge phones they intend to slide a SIM card into for customers intent on picking one up. But, you should never pick up a new one that has been completely discharged. Storing without charge can damage lithium based batteries. You never know how long such a device was sitting in the shelf like that. Footnotes[1] Batteries - Maximizing Performance

It depends….. Steve Jobs stated he was always pissed when he bought a device, hoping to turn it on when he got it, only to find the instructions “Charge 12–18 hours before first use”. Apple used to charge their phones to 80% before shipment as storing a Li-Ion battery at 80% charge results in maximum life. But recently, intentional regulations went into effect prohibiting mass-shipping Li-Ion batteries charged over 20 (or was it 10?) % by air so the devices no longer are almost fully charged.

My iPad6 had about 40% left. Enough for me to set up the iPad, register it, sign up for Apple care+, and play with it for a while. Not complaining as in the good old days, I got a new, factory fresh KindleFire HD, and had to charge the stupid thing before I could do anything with it!
All iPhones are charged to 100% when made, but by the time they get shipped and delivered to the Apple store or your house the battery will have decreased, you may get 50–60%. Which is normal.
